newsitem.title: KENYA: Kenya shilling weakens, market still jittery.
newsitem.headline: Kenya shilling weakens, market still jittery.

text.p: The Kenyan shilling maintained its losing streak against the dollar on Monday on importer demand amid nervous trading, commercial bank dealers said.
The Central Bank of Kenya posted a mean commercial rate of 55.22 against the dollar from 54.85 on Friday. Against the pound, the shilling was posted at 89.69 from 89.04.
Dealers said even at the current levels -- 55.00/55/50 -- the shilling was still trying to find its footing.
"The market is still confused. People are maintaining wide spreads because they're not even sure they should sell at 55.50," one dealer said.

Last week, dealers said a lot of the jitters in the market were a result of the absence from the market of the central bank. They said previously, the central banks' buying rates gave an indication of where rates should be.
"What is happening now is that no one wants to be caught in any position. Everyone wants to be in a square position as much as possible," one dealer said.
The money market was tight with overnight rates quoted at 21-22 percent compared to 23 percent on Friday.
